Oh well, now I can't build this :-(

```
Error   182 Metadata file 'D:\src\reef\lang\cs\bin\x64\Debug\Org.Apache.REEF.Examples.HelloCLRBridge\Org.Apache.REEF.Examples.HelloCLRBridge.exe' could not be found    D:\src\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests\CSC   Org.Apache.REEF.Tests
```

It is referenced in REEF.tests project 
    <ProjectReference Include="$(SolutionDir)\Org.Apache.REEF.Examples.HelloCLRBridge\Org.Apache.REEF.Examples.HelloCLRBridge.csproj">
      <Project>{159f7d70-8acc-4d97-9f6d-2fc4ca0d8682}</Project>
      <Name>Org.Apache.REEF.Examples.HelloCLRBridge</Name>
    </ProjectReference>

After build, it should appear at .\lang\cs\bin\x64\Debug\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests

What is CSC in your test folder?

Thank you.
Since our resources are created in NetworkMessagingTest, it is hard to make them closed by using try-with-resources in NetworkConnectionServiceTest.
To do this, we shoud make NetworkMessagingTest class implement autoclosable, but I think this change is not good in our case.

I tested HelloREEF.NET on HDI, which doesn't work. The Evaluator fails to launch:

```
WARNING: Failed evaluator: container_1435140537414_0106_01_000002
org.apache.reef.exception.EvaluatorException: Evaluator [container_1435140537414_0106_01_000002] is assumed to be in state [SUBMITTED]. But the resource manager reports it to be in state [FAILED]. This most likely means that the Evaluator suffered a failure before establishing a communications link to the driver.
    at org.apache.reef.runtime.common.driver.evaluator.EvaluatorManager.onResourceStatusMessage(EvaluatorManager.java:546)
    at org.apache.reef.runtime.common.driver.resourcemanager.ResourceStatusHandler.onNext(ResourceStatusHandler.java:57)
    at org.apache.reef.runtime.common.driver.resourcemanager.ResourceStatusHandler.onNext(ResourceStatusHandler.java:34)
    at org.apache.reef.runtime.yarn.driver.REEFEventHandlers.onResourceStatus(REEFEventHandlers.java:91)
    at org.apache.reef.runtime.yarn.driver.YarnContainerManager.handleContainerError(YarnContainerManager.java:312)
    at org.apache.reef.runtime.yarn.driver.YarnContainerManager.onStartContainerError(YarnContainerManager.java:194)
    at org.apache.hadoop.yarn.client.api.async.impl.NMClientAsyncImpl$StatefulContainer$StartContainerTransition.onExceptionRaised(NMClientAsyncImpl.java:401)
    at org.apache.hadoop.yarn.client.api.async.impl.NMClientAsyncImpl$StatefulContainer$StartContainerTransition.transition(NMClientAsyncImpl.java:390)
    at org.apache.hadoop.yarn.client.api.async.impl.NMClientAsyncImpl$StatefulContainer$StartContainerTransition.transition(NMClientAsyncImpl.java:363)
    at org.apache.hadoop.yarn.state.StateMachineFactory$MultipleInternalArc.doTransition(StateMachineFactory.java:385)
    at org.apache.hadoop.yarn.state.StateMachineFactory.doTransition(StateMachineFactory.java:302)
    at org.apache.hadoop.yarn.state.StateMachineFactory.access$300(StateMachineFactory.java:46)
    at org.apache.hadoop.yarn.state.StateMachineFactory$InternalStateMachine.doTransition(StateMachineFactory.java:448)
    at org.apache.hadoop.yarn.client.api.async.impl.NMClientAsyncImpl$StatefulContainer.handle(NMClientAsyncImpl.java:498)
    at org.apache.hadoop.yarn.client.api.async.impl.NMClientAsyncImpl$ContainerEventProcessor.run(NMClientAsyncImpl.java:557)
    at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1145)
    at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:615)
    at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
```

Unfortunately, I don't get logs for the Evaluator.
I will look at it.
I have completed my pass.

Distributed cache management is very hard, and it is very easy to create a situation in which cached entries on different machines are inconsistent with each other or the new ground truth. Also, the Java code does address some, but not all of the issues at hand.

A couple of ideas:
1. Maybe we need a push-based protocol from the name server to the resolvers. That way, cache invalidations could be systems-controlled instead of application controlled.
2. When resolving a name, one gets the last state the evaluator-side resolver has. If the communication doesn't work, application code has to query again to see whether something changed.

Much of that second item could be hidden in the group communications library. Application code wouldn't have to think about this.

@bgchun Can you help us out here? What are some of the concerns with distributed caching we need to pay attention to? What's the textbook design for this?

@johnyangk Please ping me when ready for another round of reviews. I'd like to understand this project a little better.

I did a quick parse. One high-level bit that stood out is the liberal use of `public`. Given that we promise not to break `public` APIs in between REEF versions, we should be very careful with it. For instance, I don't think the vortex driver needs to be `public`, just its configuration.
@sears You might find this project interesting, and a bit of a deja-vu :-)
@dkm2110 As per our offline discussions, this PR should be closed, right?

[REEF-pull-request-windows3 #37](https://builds.apache.org/job/REEF-pull-request-windows3/37/) ABORTED
I'll test this.
Build and test worked on the first try for me. As my machine(s) are the best at finding build troubles, this is great news. I'll merge.

@markusweimer Thanks!
@johnyangk Let me know after you're done with the pass with @markusweimer and address my comments.

@markusweimer This's hidden in the pile of many emails I got. :)
You're right on the spot. There are two main design choices you can do. Sometimes, people use both of them. 
If you expect that the scale is not large and there is little change, the first may be reasonable. But as soon as you have changes to update, you have to broadcast the changes to the clients even though the changes are not used at the client. This design has a scalability concern. So, typically, changes are propagated through a scalable pub-sub system. This's not the design choice I had in mind for `NetworkService`.
The second one incurs additional latency when the mapping between id and address becomes stale, but it's easier to get scalable in our setting (`Driver` runs an instance for serving name lookups). This's the design I had in mind initially.
